title: An ancient and variable mannose-binding lectin from the coral Acropora millepora binds both pathogens and symbionts
abstract: Corals form the framework of the world's coral reefs and are under threat from increases in disease and bleaching (symbiotic dysfunction), yet the mechanisms of pathogen and symbiont recognition remain largely unknown. Here we describe the isolation and characterisation of an ancient mannose-binding lectin in the coral Acropora millepora, which is likely to be involved in both processes. The lectin ('Millectin') was isolated by affinity chromatography and was shown to bind to bacterial pathogens as well as coral symbionts, dinoflagellates of the genus Symbiodinium. cDNA analysis of Millectin indicate extensive sequence variation in the binding region, reflecting its ability to recognise various mannose-like carbohydrate structures on non-self cells, including symbionts and pathogens. This is the first mannose-binding lectin to show extensive sequence variability as observed for pattern recognition proteins in other invertebrate immune systems and, given that invertebrates rely on non-adaptive immunity, is a potential keystone component of coral defence mechanisms.

abstract.text: Corals form the framework of the world's coral reefs and are under threat from increases in disease and bleaching (symbiotic dysfunction), yet the mechanisms of pathogen and symbiont recognition remain largely unknown. Here we describe the isolation and characterisation of an ancient mannose-binding lectin in the coral Acropora millepora, which is likely to be involved in both processes. The lectin ('Millectin') was isolated by affinity chromatography and was shown to bind to bacterial pathogens as well as coral symbionts, dinoflagellates of the genus Symbiodinium. cDNA analysis of Millectin indicate extensive sequence variation in the binding region, reflecting its ability to recognise various mannose-like carbohydrate structures on non-self cells, including symbionts and pathogens. This is the first mannose-binding lectin to show extensive sequence variability as observed for pattern recognition proteins in other invertebrate immune systems and, given that invertebrates rely on non-adaptive immunity, is a potential keystone component of coral defence mechanisms.

body_text.text: Scleractinian corals are sessile marine invertebrates that form the framework of coral reefs and sustain an enormous biodiversity. However, coral reefs are experiencing increased levels of stress from a range of factors including diseases and bleaching-loss of their algal symbionts (Symbiodinium) [1] [2] [3] . There has been a rapid increase in investigation of coral diseases and stress responses over the last decade, yet study of the scleractinian coral immune system remains in its infancy. Little is known about the molecular mechanisms underlying pathogen defence and symbiont uptake in corals despite their inherent association with coral disease and bleaching. A fundamental feature of the innate immune system of all metazoans is the ability to identify non-self utilising pattern recognition receptors (PRRs) to recognise and bind surface structures on external foreign entities [4] . A PRR binding event can initiate signalling cascades that induce a downstream immune response or immediate reactions such as agglutination of invading cells and opsonisation for phagocytosis [4, 5] . In addition, agglutination and phagocytosis assist in symbiont uptake by animals [6, 7] . We therefore hypothesised that keystone elements of non-self recognition in both coral immune responses and symbiotic processes may be found amongst the pattern recognition proteins. The interest in invertebrate PRRs has also increased over the last few years as it has become evident that invertebrates may utilise an alternative adaptive immune system involving highly variable PRRs [8] [9] [10] [11] [12] [13] . An important group of PRRs in vertebrates and invertebrates are the lectins, proteins that can recognise carbohydrate structures on non-self cells [14] [15] [16] . Mannans, consisting of multiple densely packed terminal mannose residues, are abundant carbohydrate entities on the surface of nonmetazoan cells and function as key targets for several lectins involved in immunity, including that of the well-studied vertebrate mannose-binding lectin (MBL) [17] . Bioinformatics studies on expressed genes have found that corals appear to have high ancestral complexity and have many genes in common with vertebrates [18] . Some of these genes do not appear in many other invertebrates, suggesting extensive gene loss in these taxa [18] . Hence, studies into coral immunity may provide novel information on the evolution of the early innate immune system of animals. One example reflecting the presence of unexpected immune-related genes in corals is the discovery of complement C3 [19, 20] . This molecule interacts with MBL in a complex system in vertebrates and a more simplified system in higher invertebrates, further fuelling the interest to investigate coral lectins with preference for mannose. We used mannose affinity chromatography to isolate a protein from the coral Acropora millepora that we have named Millectin, which is the first functional PRR to be described in a scleractinian coral. The protein binds both pathogens and algal symbionts, suggesting lectins may have been co-opted from an ancient innate immune system into a role in selecting and maintaining the photosynthetic endosymbionts in reef-building corals. Millectin is an ancient relative of the collectins MBL and SP-A and has extensive sequence variation in the binding region, providing insight into the function and evolution of the innate immune system.

A. millepora used in this study was collected from the reef flat on Heron Island, Great Barrier Reef, Australia (23127 0 12 00 S, 151155 0 47 00 E). Fragments of 10 Â 10 cm were transported live to the laboratory where protein extractions were performed. Coral fragments destined for RNA extraction and subsequent cDNA library construction were snap frozen in liquid nitrogen immediately after collection and stored at À80 1C. Bacterial isolates used in this study all came from the Aquatic Animal Health Laboratory strain collection at the University of Queensland (UQ) with the exception of Vibrio coralliilyticus, which was isolated from mucus of A. millepora from Heron Island. Maintained Symbiodinium cultures were provided by Eugenia Sampayo, Centre for Marines Studies, UQ. All chemicals used in this study came from Sigma (Castle Hill, Australia) unless stated otherwise.

A coral piece was collected using gloves from the reef flat at Heron Island, rinsed in filter-sterilised (0.22 mm) seawater to remove loosely associated microbes and allowed to produce mucus (from air exposure) for 30 s. A mucus drop was spread onto a marine agar plate (BD Bioscience, USA) and grown at 25 1C overnight. Individual colonies of interest were picked and re-streaked. Ribosomal 16s DNA (rDNA) was amplified from pure isolates in a PCR reaction according to Lane 1991 [21] utilising primers 27f (5 0 -AGA GTT TGA TCM TGG CTC AG-3 0 ) and 1492r (5 0 -TAC GGY TAC CTT GTT ACG ACT T-3 ) [21] . Purified PCR products were sequenced in both directions by the Australian Genome Research Facility (AGRF, Brisbane, Australia).
body_text.section: Isolation of V. coralliilyticus from A. millepora

body_text.text: The lectin was isolated and purified using mannose affinity chromatography essentially as described for teleost lectins by Ewart et al. [22] with some modifications. Briefly, coral tissue and mucus were removed by airbrushing coral pieces into ice-cold sterile Tris-buffered calcium saline (TCS; 10 mM Tris-HCl, 150 mM NaCl, 10 mM CaCl 2 , pH 7.4) with additions of 0.5 mM phenylmethyl sulfonyl fluoride and 1 mg ml À1 each of pepstatin and leupeptin. The resultant slurry was homogenised and coral algal symbionts removed by centrifugation at 1500g for 10 min at 4 1C. Coral tissues were again homogenised and centrifuged at 5600g for 1 h at 4 1C to remove membranes and debris. Non-specific agarosebinding proteins were removed from the supernatant using agarose beads (Ultragel-A4, Sigma, Castle Hill, Australia), prior to affinity chromatography. Mannose-binding proteins were recovered by affinity by incubation of the supernatant with mannan-conjugated agarose beads (Sigma, Castle Hill, Australia), for 10 h at 4 1C. The beads and bound proteins were then packed into 5 ml Econo-Pac columns (BioRad, Gladesville, Australia) for washing and elution. The columns were washed with 3 column volumes of TCS, and protein was eluted in sterile Tris-buffered saline (TBS; 10 mm Tris-HCl, 150 mM NaCl, pH 7.4) containing D-(+)-mannose (200 mM). The eluate was collected in 50 ml aliquots.
body_text.section: Isolation of lectin (Millectin) from A. millepora

body_text.text: All sodium dodecyl sulphate polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis (SDS-PAGE) was performed in a Hoeffer SE260 electrophoresis unit (GE Healthcare, Rydalmere, Australia). Proteins were separated in discontinuous gels comprising 12% acrylamide resolving gels overlayed with 4% acrylamide stacking gels. Molecular weights were estimated by comparison with Precision plus prestained standards (BioRad, Gladesville, Australia). Purity and structure of proteins was determined under reducing (200 mM dithiothreitol, 6 min, 99 1C) or non-reducing conditions. Gels were stained with silver SNAP s Stain kit II (Pierce, Rockford, IL, USA) according to the manufacturer's instructions.

Fractions of eluted Millectin destined for N-terminal sequencing were combined and dialysed into low salt buffer (0.2 mM Tris-HCl, 3 mM NaCl, pH 7.4), then concentrated by lyophilisation and the resulting pellet resuspended in sterile water. All dialysis in this study was carried out using Slide-A-Lyzer s dialysis cassettes (Pierce, Rockford, IL, USA). The concentrated protein was separated by SDS-PAGE on a 12% gel, as described above, and subsequently blotted onto a PDVF membrane (Immobilon P, Millipore, North Ryde, Australia) in CAPS buffer using a semi-dry blotting apparatus (Semi-Phor TE70, GE Healthcare, Rydalmere, Australia). The PDVF membrane was stained with 1% Naphthol Blue black according to the manufacturer's instructions, from which bands of interest were excised for N-terminal amino acid sequencing by Edman degradation utilising an Applied Biosystems Procise 492cLC.

A frozen coral branch from 1 individual (immediately snap frozen in liquid nitrogen) was ground under liquid nitrogen. Total RNA was isolated from the resulting tissue slurry using the Qiagen mRNA Midi-Prep Kit (Qiagen, Oslo, Norway) in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions. The quality of the RNA was checked by electrophoresis. mRNA was purified using a Poly A Purist kit (Ambion, Austin, TX, USA) and subsequently used to construct a directional library (l-ZAP II vector) using a kit (Stratagene, La Jolla, CA, USA).
body_text.section: Isolation of mRNA and cDNA library construction

body_text.text: The constructed cDNA library was screened to obtain full cDNA sequence of the protein using degenerate primers constructed from the obtained N-terminals sequence (2UN5r 5 0 -ACNGCYTTYTCIATRTTYTC-3 , 2UN7f 5 -AARGCNGTNGAYC-CITGYGG-3 0 , 2UN6r 5 -GGRTCNACNGCYTTYTCIATRTT-3 ). PCR reactions were set up using Platinum Taq DNA polymerase (Invitrogen, Melbourne, Australia) and amplifications were performed in an Eppendorf Mastercycler Gradient EP S (Eppendorf, Hamburg, Germany) using a temperature gradient from 48 to 63 1C and the following protocol: 94 1C for 3 min (1 cycle); 94 1C for 45 s, annealing temperature (48-63 1C) for 45 s, and 72 1C for 90 s (30 cycles); 72 1C for 10 min (1 cycle). PCR products were ligated into a pGEM T-Easy vector (Promega, WI, USA) and subsequently cloned into TOP10 cells (Invitrogen, Mel-bourne, Australia). Primers specific to Millectin (M1f 5 -TGCCAGTTATTTTCCTGGTTCT-3 0 and M1r 5 CAGCCTCTTGCA-CACTGC-3 0 ) were constructed based on deduced cDNA sequence and used in conjunction with a proofreading Taq DNA polymerase, High Fidelity Platinum Taq (Invitrogen, Melbourne, Australia) to screen the A. millepora cDNA library for isomers of Millectin. Amplifications were again performed in an Eppendorf Mastercycler Gradient EP S (Eppendorf, Hamburg, Germany) using the following protocol: 94 1C for 5 min (1 cycle); 94 1C for 1 min, 57 1C for 1 min, and 72 1C for 3 min (30 cycles); 72 1C for 10 min (1 cycle). Amplicons were cloned using pGEM T-Easy vector (Promega, WI, USA) and TOP10 cells (Invitrogen, Melbourne, Australia) and sequenced by AGRF as above. A total of 84 clones were sequenced in both directions from two independent reactions to eliminate amplification and reading errors.
body_text.section: Full cDNA sequence and investigation into cDNA isoforms

body_text.text: Sequence analysis was carried out using the NCBI blast server (BlastX), Signal P 3.0 Server [23] , Target P 1.1 server [24] and NetNGlyc 1.0 Server. All sequences were compared using DNA Star (Lasergene). Phylogenetic trees were initially constructed based on the C-type lectin domain of over 50 of the closest homologues to Millectin-utilising ClustalX (version 1.83) [25] and distance methods in PAUP* [26] . From these, relevant proteins were further selected to constitute a representative tree-utilising methods described above, where neighbour joining trees were constructed by estimation of molecular distances based on mean character difference. Boot strap values were defined using 1000 bootstrap pseudoreplications using a full heuristic search. Nexus alignment files are available upon request. The structure of Millectin was predicted using CPHmodels 2.0 server [27] and visualised using PyMOL vs 1.0 [28] . Bioinformatics tools can be viewed at www.cbs.dtu.dk/ services/. PDB files of rat MBL (1msb) [29] were downloaded from the RCSB Protein data bank and viewed in PyMOL.

Pure fractions of lectin to be used in binding assays were dialyzed into TCS to remove residual mannose and the protein concentrations were determined using a Bradford assay (Sigma, Castle Hill, Australia). All binding assays were repeated twice to ensure reproducible results.

The bacterial species Vibrio harveyi (ACM 0-53535), Streptococcus iniae (QMA0076), Bacillus licheniformis (ACM1512) and V. coralliilyticus (isolated from A. millepora from the GBR) were extensively washed and then diluted in TCS to an OD 600 ¼ 1.5. Coral lectin and control (bovine serum albumin-BSA) suspensions were mixed with bacterial suspensions, incubated at 25 1C for 15 min, and images captured using a light microscope equipped with a digital camera (Olympus BX41). Dose-dependant agglutination was tested using 2 different concentrations of Millectin (10 and 50 mg ml À1 ). The dependency on Ca 2+ for agglutination was investigated for all bacteria used in this study by addition of 1 mM EDTA to a sample with bacteria (OD of 1) with calcium (20 mM Ca 2+ ).

For 3 days prior to the binding assays, Symbiodinium was treated with an antibiotic mix [30] to remove any bacterial contaminants. Immediately prior to the assay, Symbiodinium was extensively washed to remove any residual antibiotics or algal exudates. Symbiodinium was diluted in TCS to an OD 600 ¼ 1.5. Lectin and BSA (control) were biotinylated using EZ-Link TM Sulfo NHS-Biotin (Pierce, Rockford, IL, USA) following the manufacturer's protocol and subsequently dialysed into TCS (Slide-A-Lyzer s dialysis cassettes, Pierce, Rockford, IL, USA). Symbiodinium cultures were mixed with biotinylated lectin or BSA and incubated at 25 1C for 1 h prior to extensively repeated washes. Fluorescein (FITC) conjugated immunopure s avidin (Pierce, Rockford, IL, USA) was added to aliquots according to manufacturer's protocol. Binding of biotinylated protein to Symbiodinium was viewed on a scanning laser confocal microscope (Zeiss LSM 510 Meta) fitted with Cy3 (560-615 nm; red) and FITC (505-530 nm; green) filters.

Eluates from the mannose affinity chromatography yielded purified aliquots of mannose-binding protein. The subunit structure of the protein was determined by SDS-PAGE in which two bands of 16 and 17 kDa were detected (Figure 1 ). N-terminal sequencing of these bands confirmed that they possessed identical N-terminal amino acid sequence (GILE-NIEKAVDPCGDV). The size variation is likely to represent glycosylated (17 kDa) and non-glycosylated (16 kDa) subunit isoforms, reflected by sequence variation in the N-glycosylation site at N 136 X 137 S/T/A 138 in isoforms encoded in different transcripts (Figure 2 ). Separation of native Millectin indicated that the mature protein consisted of trimers ($50 kDa) under non-reducing conditions. A dimeric or degradation product of 30 kDa was also detected under non-reduced conditions (Figure 1 ).
body_text.section: Isolation, purification and amino acid sequencing of Millectin

body_text.text: cDNA cloning, sequence analysis and phylogenetic tree construction PCR reactions utilising degenerate primers constructed from the deduced amino acid sequence yielded the full-length cDNA sequence (Figure 2 ). The sequence appears complete with start codon and associated poly A tail. The amino acid sequence determined by Edman degradation was located in the predicted protein, confirming its identity and suggesting that N-terminal cleavage has occurred as the deduced Nterminal sequence appears first in amino acid position 54 of the full-length predicted protein ( Figure 2 ). The predicted processed protein from deduced N-terminal sequence corresponds to the estimated size of Millectin determined by SDS-PAGE, further confirming the identity of the protein (Figures 1 and 2) . Sequence analysis revealed that the protein contains a signal peptide for secretion, although this is shorter than the cleaved product. The protein contains a C-type lectin domain in the C-terminal of the protein, with a conserved EPN (mannose-binding) motif and a predicted N-glycosylation site. While the short N-terminal of Millectin shares no sequence homology with previously characterised proteins, the C-type lectin domain that spans the majority of the sequence (Figures 2 and 3) is homologous, and shares vital amino acid positions (Figure 3 ) with the lectin domain of a range of C-type lectins involved in immunity in other animals. These include vertebrate CD23, SP-A, mannose receptor, DC-SIGN and MBL (Figure 3) . Phylogenetic analysis indicates that Millectin is closely related to the two important members of the collectin family, vertebrate MBL and SP-A (Figure 4) . However, the protein lacks the collagen component found in vertebrate collectins.
body_text.section: Isolation, purification and amino acid sequencing of Millectin

body_text.text: Millectin bound to, and agglutinated, both Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria. Agglutination by Millectin was observed for the marine pathogens V. harveyi and S. iniae, the ubiquitous marine and soil bacterium B. licheniformis and the coral pathogen V. coralliilyticus [31] (Figure 5) . No agglutination was observed in controls with BSA. Dose-and Ca 2+ -dependant agglutinations were observed for all bacteria used in this study, where increased levels of Millectininduced increased levels of agglutination and addition of EDTA disrupted the agglutination capabilities. Subsequent additions of excess calcium restored the agglutination ( Figure 5 ). As Symbiodinium normally forms clumps (autoagglutinates) in vitro, agglutination assays were not appropriate to assess the binding of Millectin to Symbiodinium. We therefore used fluorescence microscopy to examine binding of biotinylated and FITC-conjugated purified Millectin to a variety of Symbiodinium types and found that it binds to cultured, axenic Symbiodinium types C1, C2 and A2 when in the presence of calcium ( Figure 6) . No binding was observed in controls using BSA.

A total of 13 distinct isoforms of Millectin were observed from 84 sequences. All variants existed in two or more clones, eliminating random sequencing errors as a source of variation. Moreover, the positions of these amino acid substitutions were highly conserved and occurred at 14 non-random positions in a 196 amino acid-long sequence of the protein (Figure 7a) . No amino acid substitutions occurred in any of the conserved structural motifs such as the calcium-or mannose-binding sites. Comparisons of the resolved structure of the C-type lectin domain of rat MBL and a 3D prediction model of Millectin reveal similarities in folding and areas of carbohydrate binding (Figure 7b ). The Millectin model indicated that the majority of the substitutions appear in areas in close proximity to the carbohydratebinding site (Figure 7b ). All the sequence variation in the C-type lectin fold of Millectin occurs in the loops and not in the helical structures or b-sheets that create the backbone of the lectin fold.
body_text.section: Amino acid variations and structure variations

body_text.text: As the ability to distinguish non-self from self is one of the most crucial and important aspects of an immune system, we considered this to be the logical starting point for investigating immune responses in an organism for which functional data are scarce. In doing so, we have isolated and identified a PRR that is of interest from a range of perspectives including a potential role in symbiosis, diversity in invertebrate immune receptors and the evolution of players in the innate immune system. Millectin is homologous to the lectin domain of a range of C-type lectins involved in immunity in other animals. These include vertebrate CD23, SP-A, mannose receptor, DC-SIGN and MBL where the latter four recognise a range of viruses, bacteria, fungi and protists [14, 16, 32] and CD23 binds IgE, functioning as a cytokine and mediator of inflammation [33] . Millectin, in common with several of its homologues, has a conserved carbohydrate-binding site (EPN) in position 158-160, which confers specificity predominantly for mannose and similar carbohydrates such as fucose, N-acetylglucosamine and glucose [17, 34] , and shows Ca 2+ dependency in common with many C-type lectins [15] . Electrophoretic separation of native Millectin indicated that the mature protein consists of trimers, similar to the basic trimeric or multiple trimer configurations observed in CD23, SP-A and vertebrate mannan-binding lectin [32, 35, 36] . Further, phylogenetic analysis indicates that Millectin is closely related to two members of the collectin family, vertebrate MBL and SP-A, which are both vital first lines of defence in innate and adaptive immune responses [14, 32] . Based on these analyses, we propose that Millectin, MBL and SP-A are a conserved group of PRRs that evolved from a proto-MBL gene that was present in the last common ancestor to cnidarians and bilaterians. The suggested relationship between these molecules is further supported by similarities in binding targets, oligomeric structure, function and presumptive tertiary structure as discussed in this paper. Millectin appears to lack the collagen component characteristic of higher vertebrate collectins, as has been observed in a urochordate ascidian MBL-like protein, lending further support to the suggestion that the collagen structure evolved specifically in vertebrates [37] . The ascidian lectin interacts with complement factor C3 in a primitive complement system [38] and, hence, warrants further investigations on the interactions of Millectin and a recently discovered C3 in coral [19, 20] .

Given the similarities to other lectin PRRs and the ancient relationship to MBL and SP-A, we investigated the binding and function of Millectin in vitro. Mucus that is secreted by and surrounds corals is a microbe-rich environment with high densities of a diverse range of bacterial groups [39] . Therefore, corals are likely to have evolved an effective defence against obligate or opportunistic pathogens, presumably using PRRs to recognise microbes. We found that Millectin bound to and agglutinated both Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria, including the coral pathogen V. coralliilyticus, indicative of multivalent cell surface binding properties to non-self structures. The ability to bind and immobilise a variety of bacteria, including those implicated in disease, shows Millectin is a functional PRR in the coral immune system. By binding and agglutinating potential invaders, Millectin has the potential to prevent movement and dispersal of the pathogen through the host and enable opsonisation (i.e. targeting) for phagocytosis and destruction [5] .

Despite the vast bacterial communities associated with corals, the most studied of the coral-associated microbes remains the symbiotic dinoflagellate Symbiodinium, which resides within a vacuolar membrane inside the gastrodermal cells of the coral. Through photosynthesis, they contribute the majority of the host's energy requirements [40] . This beneficial, yet pervasive endosymbiotic mutualism provides the energy required for the accretion of calcium carbonate skeletons of corals and hence the framework of coral reefs. As many corals must acquire new symbionts from the environment at each generation, mechanisms must exist for the identification and targeting of Symbiodinium for phagocytosis from the surrounding seawater [41] . C-type lectins have previously been shown to play a role in harvesting microbial symbionts. For example, in the marine nematode Laxus oneistus, the DC-SIGN-like protein Mermaid is secreted into the cuticle mucus layer, where it mediates bacterial symbiont acquisition by binding and agglutination [6] . Although there is no direct evidence that C-type lectins are involved in phagocytosis of Symbiodinium, it appears that lectin/glycan interactions mediate symbiont uptake in corals [42] . We used fluorescence microscopy to examine binding of biotinylated and FITC-conjugated purified Millectin to a variety of Symbiodinium types and found that it binds to cultured, axenic Symbiodinium types C1, C2 and A2 when in the presence of calcium. Two major functions of the relatives to Millectin are agglutination and opsonisation, and the coating of Symbiodinium by Millectin is essentially identical to the binding of opsonins to targets destined for phagocytosis. As Millectin contains a signal peptide for extracellular secretion, we propose that the protein is secreted into the mucus layer coating the surface and gut of corals, where it binds non-self mannan structures on both symbionts and pathogens causing agglutination and immobilisation of microbes, and binding and opsonisation of symbionts or bacteria that are destined to be phagocytosed. The onset of symbiosis is mediated by selection processes occurring both before and after phagocytosis [7] and we suggest that an ancient role of C-type lectins in the innate immune response has been co-opted into the pathway that leads to the uptake of Symbiodinium by corals. Unknown signalling cascades downstream of the phagocytosis event may then determine whether the Symbiodinium type takes up residence in the coral cell or not. The inability to identify specific genes involved in coral/dinoflagellate symbiosis [43] is compatible with our proposal that this pathway evolved by co-opting existing genes and pathways into this novel role.

Symbiodinium may act in a similar way to intracellular pathogens that utilise host PRRs to enter cells and thereafter modulate the host response for survival [44] . This hypothesis becomes increasingly intriguing when considering the evolutionary position of Symbiodinium, as these organisms are closely related to the apicomplexans, a group which contains a number of intracellular pathogens [45] .

Putative PRRs, such as Dscam, FREP, PGRPs and SRCR, have been identified in a range of invertebrates, where they show high-sequence diversity resulting from alternative splicing or expanded gene families [8] [9] [10] [11] [12] . It has been hypothesised that this variability functions as an alternative adaptive immune system in invertebrates allowing for rapid diversification of the innate immune system in order to compete with evolutionary changes of pathogen surfaces No substitutions are observed in the highly conserved C-type lectin residues (boxed) or in predicted mannose and calcium-binding sites (denoted by dots below residue). Sequence variation in a predicted glycosylation site (underlined), is assumed to result in non-glycosylated and glycosylated isoforms. (b), PyMOL 3D view of the C-type lectin domain of resolved MBL (PDB; 1msb, left) and predicted Millectin (right) modelled upon PDB structure 1t8c. Blue sticks show the mannosebinding site (EPN) and additional known or predicted calcium-binding sites. Regions highlighted in red in the Millectin model indicate the positions of amino acid variation seen in (a) for the C-type lectin domain, and show that variation only occurs in the loops of the predicted model. [13] . Small changes in the primary amino acid sequence of the carbohydrate-binding region in lectins can significantly alter the affinity and specificity of the target [34] and, interestingly, we discovered 13 distinct isoforms of Millectin when we sequenced 84 clones from a cDNA library derived from mRNA from a single individual. The positions of these amino acid substitutions were highly conserved, suggesting the variations were not due to sequencing or cloning errors. Comparisons of the resolved structure of the C-type lectin domain of rat MBL and a 3D prediction model of Millectin reveal similarities in folding and areas of carbohydrate binding. The Millectin model indicated that the majority of the substitutions appear in areas in close proximity to the carbohydrate-binding site. The C-type lectin fold has been shown to tolerate extensive sequence variation without altering the overall fold of the domain, permitting substitutions in non-structural segments [46] . In line with this, all the sequence variation in the C-type lectin fold of Millectin occurs in the loops and not in the helical structures or b-sheets that create the backbone of the lectin fold. In addition, no amino acid substitutions occur in any of the conserved structural motifs such as the calcium-or mannose-binding sites, suggesting these functions remain intact in all isoforms. Whilst MBL in vertebrates has evolved to participate in processes involving the adaptive immune system, we suggest that Millectin has diversified its binding repertoire to distinguish non-self organisms, including that of pathogens and symbionts. The diversification of Millectin may simultaneously increase the efficiency of the innate immune system and extend this process to include symbiont acquisition. Millectin is the first mannose-binding lectin shown to contain extensive sequence variation, as observed in other invertebrate PRRs. Although we have only discovered 13 variants of Millectin, far fewer than the thousands of isoforms suggested for Dscam, Millectin assumes a trimeric configuration that would generate a considerable amount of diversity with over 2000 possible multimeric variations, if all possible combinations were utilised.

In summary, we have characterised the first functional PRR from a scleractinian coral, a new addition to variable PRRs in invertebrate immunity. The presence of a functional mannose-binding lectin in coral indicates that this gene family predates the divergence of cnidarians and bilaterians and suggests that MBLs have an ancient and well-conserved role in eumetazoan innate immunity. The sequence diversity in the binding region reflects the ability of Millectin to recognise and bind a range of exogenous organisms, including beneficial symbionts. Our findings suggest that Millectin has multiple functions, co-opted from the innate immune system to fulfil key roles in both immunity and symbiont acquisition. The relationship between these two functions is intriguing, as the phenomena of coral disease and bleaching events becomes increasingly significant to the health of coral reefs around the world.
Mannose-binding lectin from the coral A. millepora

back_matter.text: This work was supported in part by grants from the PADI Foundation, the Australian Coral Reef Society and the ARC Centre of Excellence for Coral Reef studies (to OHG). We thank E. Sampayo for providing Symbiodinium cultures and knowledge of PAUP, and J. Hill and T. Ainsworth for assistance with the Zeiss LSM 510 Meta. We also thank J. Roff and J. Davy for valuable comments.

FIGREF0.text: Subunit structure of the coral C-type lectin Millectin. Subunit structure of purified Millectin from A. millepora on a 12% SDS-PAGE gel viewed by silverstain. Bands indicate Millectin contains subunits of 16 and 17 kDa (reduced conditions, lane 1). The size variation is likely to represent glycosylated (17 kDa) and non-glycolylated (16 kDa) subunit isoforms. Separation of native Millectin (lane 2) shows bands in the 50 and 30 kDa size range, representing trimeric and dimeric (or degradation product) configurations of Millectin.

FIGREF1.text: cDNA and derived amino acid sequence of Millectin (EU717895). Black boxes indicate a predicted signal sequence. Grey box shows the amino acid sequence determined from N-terminal sequencing. Black underlined area indicates the sequence span of an identified C-type lectin domain. Grey box with asterisk denotes a conserved EPN (mannose-binding) motif. The area of a predicted N-glycosylation site is twice underlined in black.

FIGREF2.text: Alignments of Millectin to C-type lectins involved in immunity. Shading indicates homology (black-100%, grey-80% and light grey-60%). Asterisk below sequence indicates the start of the C-type lectin domain and dots below alignment denote the conserved amino acids in the mannose-and the calcium-binding sites. Accession numbers as follows: coral Millectin (EU717895), human MBL2 (P11226), human SP-A (Q81IWL2), human CD23 (P06734), human DC-SIGN (Q9NNX6), ascidian lectin (MBL-like protein) (Q95YN3).

FIGREF3.text: Phylogenetic relationship of Millectin and the collectin family members MBL and SP-A. Phylogenetic tree constructed based on distance methods showing bootstrap values and branch lengths. The tree indicates that Millectin is an ancient relative of the common ancestor of vertebrate MBL and SP-A. Protein accession numbers and nexus files available on request.

FIGREF4.text: Binding of Millectin to bacteria. Bacterial agglutination by Millectin from the coral A. millepora. Agglutination (clumping of cells) is indicative of binding of Millectin to cells surfaces and is evident in samples containing 50 mg ml À1 Millectin and bacteria with an OD of 1: (a), B. licheniformis; (b), V. coralliilyticus; (c), S. iniae and (h) and (i), V. harveyi. Corresponding controls with bacteria (OD 600 of 1) and 50 mg ml À1 bovine serum albumin (BSA) show no agglutination: (d), B. licheniformis; (e), V. coralliilyticus; (f), S. iniae and (j), V. harveyi. Representative figures of dose-dependant agglutination are shown in (g), V. harveyi with 10 mg ml À1 of Millectin and (h), V. harveyi with 50 mg ml À1 of Millectin showing increased agglutination. Magnification on (h) is shown in (i). Representative example of Ca 2+ -dependant agglutination is shown in (k), where addition of 1 mM EDTA to V. harveyi (OD 600 of 1) with mg ml À1 of Millectin prevents agglutination and (l), subsequent addition of excess calcium (20 mM Ca 2+ ) to sample shown in (k) restores agglutination. All figures are representative photos from repeated experiments with consistent results. Scalebars are 20 mm.

FIGREF5.text: Binding of Millectin to Symbiodinium. Binding of Millectin to various Symbiodinium types visualised on a confocal microscope, with biotinylated and FITC-conjugated Millectin shown in green and Symbiodinium cells in red. Symbiodinium (OD 600 of 1) with 30 mg ml À1 Millectin shows binding of Millectin as halo-like rings (green) surrounding Symbiodinium (red): (a), clade C1; (b), clade C2; (c), clade A2. Controls of Symbiodinium (OD 600 of 1) with 30 mg ml À1 BSA show no binding: (d), clade C1; (e), clade C2; (f), clade A2. All figures are representative photos from repeated experiments with consistent results. Scalebars are 10 mm.

FIGREF6.text: Targeted amino acid substitution sites in Millectin isoforms. (a), Clustal X alignment of 13 identified isoforms of Millectin derived from a cDNA library from 1 individual A. millepora colony. Conserved amino acids are indicated as dots while letters show the amino acid substitution in the different isoforms.
